Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding how animals communicate and cooperate in response to predators
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most conspicuous animal behaviors are related to communication. Crickets chirp, frogs chorus, and birds sing. Signals like these are not reserved for private conversation, but are inherently social signals involving numerous senders and receivers. This network perspective has been slow coming. Mobbing calls are signals used both within and across species to communicate about predators. They can encode important information about predators. Successful mobbing calls attract numerous individuals and species to the predator's location to drive it from the area. Mobbing events do not appear to be random, but organized networks with complex species interactions. Therefore, they offer unique opportunities to test the network perspective and how interspecific communication dictates species interactions and community structure. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Robert Magrath at Australian National University. Dr. Magrath is a behavioral ecologist who has been instrumental in shattering the old framework of animal communication.

This project will address how information is being encoded in mobbing calls and how this information is used by other species in a communication network. It will be one of the first applications of the network perspective to communication signals. Data from this project will add generalizability to the patterns of communication network assembly. This work will be done in the Australian National Botanic Gardens using birds that are evolutionary distinct from North American birds. The project will use playbacks and predator models to test how two Australian bird species are encoding information about predators. And with these results, a time-synched microphone array will be deployed to record which species are using the encoded information and how they are using it. The conclusions from this research will advance our understanding of animal communication, predator-prey interactions, and community assembly. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animal communication systems are all around us and often involve some of the most conspicuous behaviors we appreciate about animals. Our study of animal communication systems has focused on simple, dyadic exchanges of information between one sender and one receiver. However, animal communication systems are incredibly complex and need to be addressed with a network perspective with multiple senders, multiple receivers, and variable information to fully understand the ecology and evolution of communication systems. Part of the reason the dyadic perspective has persisted is because of technological limitations. But, microphone arrays are a new and exciting technology that allows us to record the vocalizations of multiple species across both time and space. Using this new and exciting technology, we addressed some of the holes in our understanding by asking questions about how changes in sender identity influence the responses of multiple receivers in a mobbing call communication system. Mobbing calls are used both within and across bird species to communicate about predators. Successful mobbing calls attract numerous individuals and species to the predator’s location to help drive it from the area. Mobbing events do not appear to be random, but organized communication networks with complex species interactions. Therefore, they offer unique opportunities to test how interspecific communication infleunces species interactions and community structure and organization.

We conducted this research in the Australian National Botanical Gardens in Canberra, Australia. We played back the mobbing calls of multiple common Australian birds, both individually and in combination with each other, and recorded the responses of focal bird species using 6-piece microphone arrays. This project is one of the first applications of microphone array technology to field research questions.

We found that the identity of the sender changes the response of some bird species more than others. First, all the bird species we looked at were more likely to participate in the mobbing event when the playback was of mobbing calls compared to Crimson Rosella control songs. This suggests that these species are communicating across species and listening and using one another’s mobbing calls to assess danger. We also found that not all species respond to the same senders. For example, we found that red wattlebirds only respond if the sender includes another red wattlebird. Superb fairy wrens respond more when the senders are two different species. And New Holland honeyeaters, white-browed scrubwrens and Eastern spinebills will respond to the mobbing calls of multiple species. These findings support the network perspective where multiple senders are interacting with multiple receivers and the information exchange is extremely variable across receivers.

By studying communication as a network that spans species, we advance our understanding of animal communication and behavioral ecology by shattering the outdated idea of one sender and one receiver. We also challenge our understanding of signal evolution in the presence of multiple senders and receivers and species interactions in a community by showing that communication has an important influence on species interactions and organization. This is also one of the first applications of microphone arrays to communication networks. Finally, acoustic animal communication is common, conspicuous and offers an incredible opportunity to enhance the public’s understanding and appreciation of the acoustic landscape all around us.
